message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated serum calcium and PTH level, as well as his bone pain and osteopenia, indicate primary hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management as it can help locate the abnormal parathyroid tissue. CT scan of the neck can also be used but it is less sensitive than 99mTc sestamibi scan. Bone scan (DEXA) is used for measuring bone mineral density, but it is not needed for the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism. Sestamibi scan only is not enough to localize the abnormal parathyroid tissue accurately.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest hyperparathyroidism. A sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis and management. This scan will help detect any adenomas or hyperplasia in the parathyroid gland. The other options are less relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum calcium level suggests primary hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step for diagnosing the location of the parathyroid adenoma. CT scan of the neck would not add any new information in this scenario. Bone scan can help assess the extent of bone involvement but is not necessary for diagnosis at this point. A sestamibi scan alone would not provide enough information without an ultrasound of the neck.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory findings suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma. 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step in the management for identifying the location of the adenoma. CT scan of the neck may not be sensitive enough, bone scans may detect only skeletal involvement, and sestamibi scan alone is not sufficient for locating the adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with hyperparathyroidism. In order to locate the parathyroid adenoma, 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step in his management. CT scan of the neck is not as effective at locating parathyroid adenomas. Bone scan (DEXA) is used to assess for bone density and the presence of fractures, but it is not useful in locating a parathyroid adenoma. Sestamibi scan alone is not as effective as combining it with ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings indicate hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is used to locate the adenoma responsible for the hyperparathyroidism. CT scans and bone scans are not typically used for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management to identify the abnormal parathyroid gland. CT scan of the neck or a bone scan (DEXA) may be done later for further evaluation. Sestamibi scan alone is not sufficient for identifying the abnormal parathyroid gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step to locate the parathyroid adenoma that may be causing the hyperparathyroidism. A CT scan of the neck may be performed if the sestamibi scan is negative. Bone scan (DEXA) can be used to assess the extent of bone involvement caused by the disease. Sestamibi scan alone is not enough to locate the parathyroid adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. A 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the next appropriate step as it can identify the parathyroid adenoma causing the hyperparathyroidism. CT scan of the neck can also be used but is less sensitive than sestamibi scan. Bone scan (DEXA) is useful in detecting osteoporosis but not primary hyperparathyroidism. Sestamibi scan alone is not sufficient as it may not detect the parathyroid adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, laboratory findings, and ultrasound suggest hyperparathyroidism, and a 99mTc sestamibi scan with ultrasound of the neck is the most appropriate next step to locate the parathyroid adenoma. CT scan of the neck and bone scan are not as useful in this case, and sestamibi scan only may not provide enough information.
